etymology.description: 开(open) + 心(heart) = ‘open the heart’ → happy.
etymology.interpretation: Literally ‘open the heart’, suggesting emotions are unobstructed and cheerful. Originated as a verb phrase and now commonly functions as an adjective or verb meaning to feel happy.
etymology.simplification: 開 was simplified to 开 by streamlining the 門 component and internal strokes for stroke economy; 心 remained unchanged.

examples.chinese: 我今天很开心(我今天很開心)。
这件小事就能让我开心一整天(這件小事就能讓我開心一整天)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn xiǎo shì jiù néng ràng wǒ kāixīn yī zhěng tiān.
examples.english: A small thing can keep me happy all day.

examples.chinese: 朋友讲笑话(朋友講笑話)，我们都开心地笑了(我們都開心地笑了)。
examples.pinyin: Péngyǒu jiǎng xiàohuà, wǒmen dōu kāixīn de xiàole.
examples.english: A friend told a joke, and we all laughed happily.
